data.title: SPYI Continues To Deliver Double Digit Yields With Capital Appreciation
data.description:
Covered call ETFs have become increasingly popular over the years, and the NEOS S&P 500 High Income ETF (SPYI) has amassed over $8 billion in AUM since August 2022. The JPMorgan Equity Premium Income ETF (JEPI) is still the leader in AUM for covered call ETFs with $44.49 billion, but SPYI continues to show the market why its investment strategy is superior. As the risk-free rate of return declines, it’s becoming less lucrative to park capital into risk-free assets. The United States 10-Year Bond Yield (US10Y) has fallen to 4%, while the United States 12-Month Bill Yield (US12M) has fallen to 3.51%. We have a new Fed Chair starting in May, and Goldman Sachs global head of investment grade credit, Jonny Fine, is calling for 4 rate cuts this year. I happen to agree, especially with more layoffs occurring. The Fed will need to cut to make it more viable for smaller businesses to expand and entrepreneurs to operate. In a yield-starved environment, high-yield funds will look more attractive, and SPYI has established a track record that is hard to ignore.

I think that NEOS Investments has done an incredible job generating value for shareholders and establishing a track record that works. The reality is that since inception, SPYI has delivered $20.99 in income, which is an average annualized yield of 12.21%, while appreciating by over 6%. If you're looking for income in a yield-starved environment, SPYI should continue to deliver double-digit income while gradually appreciating with the market.

Following Up on My Previous Article about SPYI

Back in October I had written an article on SPYI (can be read here) where I discussed how SPYI was still attractive as the risk-free rate of return continued to decline. I felt that SPYI stood out for its blend of appreciation and income, as its two-leg option strategy allowed it to operate in any environment. 2025 is in the books, and SPYI delivered another successful year. I am following up with another article on SPYI as I believe we will see a shift of capital from risk-free assets to income producing ETFs and CEFs to recreate the amount of income that was being produced when rates were over 5%. As that happens, I think that covered call ETFs will become more popular than they are and that SPYI can gain a significant amount of AUM. I am still very bullish on the market in 2026 and believe that SPYI is a great ETF if you're looking to produce double digit yields while having some exposure to potential upside appreciation.

SPYI Has Established a Strong Track Record over the Past 3 ½ Years that Could Continue

Investors that are focused on income are not necessarily looking for large amounts of capital appreciation; otherwise, they would just be plowing this capital into index funds or individual equities. Unless you have a misunderstanding of what covered call ETFs do, the people adding capital towards SPYI are looking for reliable recurring income. Since inception, SPYI has generated 42 consecutive monthly distributions to the tune of $20.99. This is an average monthly distribution of $0.50 which is a monthly yield of 0.96%. It’s hard to find an investment that can throw off a stable monthly yield of around 1%, and after 42 months, SPYI’s track record is solid in my opinion. There are limited fluctuations in the monthly distribution, and SPYI has been able to establish an average monthly distribution of around 12.21%.

Long-term investors were able to buy shares of SPYI at inception for $49.13 so on a $10,000 investment, 203.54 shares could have been purchased. If the distribution income was taken as cash and not reinvested back into SPYI there would have been $4,273.11 in distribution income generated. This is a 42.73% yield on cost or 12.21% annualized. Shares of SPYI are also up 6.13% since inception, which is a total return of 48.86% in 3 ½ years. Investors have been able to generate $4,885.77 of total return from SPYI. If that same $10,000 was invested in the $12 million in August of 2022 you would have generated 3.32% on your $10,000 which is $332 in income. If this was rolled over each year on an annualized basis, the total income would be roughly $1,702 and your capital would still be locked up for another 6 months. There is also no upside appreciation. The track record that SPYI has established is very strong, and I think now that the risk-free rate of return is trending towards the 3% level, it’s going to be very hard for investors to lock up capital for at least a year for low single digit yields.

I am a Big Fan of SPYI’s Framework and Tax Structure

SPYI is an actively managed ETF that has a main goal of generating high monthly income in a tax efficient manner with the potential for equity appreciation if the markets move higher. From a mechanics standpoint, SPYI owns the companies found in the S&P 500 and then runs a call options strategy on the S&P 500 Index, which includes written calls for income and purchased long calls for appreciation. Many income ETFs overwrite the portfolio by selling calls and sacrificing a lot of upside. Within the prospectus, it is clear that SPYI will leverage two sets of options to protect shareholders. SPYI will sell SPX calls on up to 100% of the equity value to harvest premium and then use part of that premium to buy out-of-the-money SPX calls. The purchased calls allow SPYI to move higher with the market to a degree because they will uncap the sold calls they wrote to generate income. This strategy allows SPYI to not lose all of the upside potential (though structurally it will lose some).

SPYI uses SPX index options that can qualify as Section 1256 contracts, which are generally treated as 60% long-term and 40% short-term capital gains, regardless of holding period. Although, it's good to note that the tax character of distributions can differ, and often is Return of Capital, which lowers investors' cost basis. SPYI also indicated that it may seek to harvest losses in equity and/or options positions to offset realized taxable gains. This is positive for long-term investors in SPYI looking for income because this framework can improve after-tax outcomes versus structures that tend to generate predominantly short-term income. Compared to other strategies, if you are holding SPYI in a taxable account, there could be significant benefits to SPYI from a tax perspective. Investors can read through the prospectus and ask an accountant for further information on this.

Even when we’re in a bull market, there are periods of volatility, which tend to spike around macro data, Fed pivots, elections, geopolitics, earnings seasons, and liquidity events. I believe that SPYI is built to monetize that volatility through systematic index option writing, and if the market declines, the structure of owning out-of-the-money calls allows it to rebound over time. ETFs that are overwriting the profile tend to cap most, if not all, of the upside potential, and when the market swings to the downside, it makes it very difficult for that fund to rebound. SPYI has allowed investors to stay in the game while generating double-digit yields on a recurring basis.

How SPYI’s Upside Capture, Downside Exposure, and NAV Drag Could Look

The most important thing to understand about SPYI’s relative performance versus the S&P 500 is that it doesn’t overwrite and cap all of the upside potential. SPYI owns the positions within the S&P 500 and then overlays index options by selling SPX calls to generate the monthly distribution and buy out of the money call options. The two-leg approach allows upside capture in SPYI. Since SPYI is taking in a net credit from the option overlay, SPYI tends to act differently within different cycles. In a modest bull market where the market rises but finishes below the short-call strike at expiration, the calls can expire worthless and the fund keeps the premium.

When this happens, investors are getting both equity upside in addition to the option premium, which allows SPYI to keep pace with the index on a total return basis. In the event of a strong rally that pushes through the short calls strike, SPYI is effectively selling away part of the upside for the immediate income. This is the core trade-off for monetizing volatility, as some of the future upside is converted into immediate income while no appreciation is realized until the long calls kick in. In a melt up situation where there is outsized upside, SPYI’s structure allows them to benefit from the long calls. The long calls begin to offset the short calls after the index moves beyond the long-call strike, which negates SPYI’s upside being permanently capped at the short strike.

When markets are declining, SPYI should be looked at as equity risk first and the option overlay second. SPYI owns the positions within the S&P 500 so if the index sells off, SPYI will follow. There is no downside protection built in from puts. The short-call premium can provide a limited cushion, but it is not comparable to the structural protection of owning protective puts. When the market has a mild downturn, the premium harvested can reduce the drawdown and help stabilize total returns, but in events like Liberation Day, when the move to the downside is violent, the premium collected is usually not large enough to offset the equity losses. When net asset value (NAV) drag gets discussed, many assume it means that SPYI is bleeding value.

There are two different concepts with NAV drag that include mechanical NAV drop from paying the distributions and the structural drag from the strategy. When SPYI pays the distribution, the NAV typically drops by roughly the distribution amount on the ex-date. This is a transfer of value from NAV into cash, and the metric to look at is total return, not the price to NAV. In a structural drag situation, the fund could underperform the index over a period of time. By trading away some upside in exchange for premium, SPYI is intentionally spending a portion of the premium to buy out-of-the-money calls. If the market doesn’t rally enough for those calls to come in the money, the premium outlay can impact the total return. SPYI is likely to work best for shareholders when the markets are range-bound to moderately bullish, and investors should expect equity equivalent drawdowns with a modest cushion from the premium when the markets fall.

Risks to Investing in SPYI

While I am bullish on SPYI, there are several risk factors to consider. SPYI has capped a lot of the upside by selling calls, and while purchasing the long calls helps, it only uncaps a portion of the potential. If the markets experience a bull market, SPYI is likely to underperform a traditional index fund. While SPYI’s distribution has been stable, the option income could change if there is less volatility in the market. Investors should make sure they understand what they are signing up for with SPYI because this fund is geared towards income, not capital appreciation. Everyone should do their own due diligence, and if you're not looking for income, SPYI is probably not the right investment for you.

Conclusion

I believe that SPYI is a strong candidate for investors who want S&P 500 exposure but also want to generate large amounts of recurring income by converting volatility into monthly distributions. SPYI is designed to give investors a chance at producing both income and appreciation, unlike traditional covered call ETFs. For investors looking for large amounts of monthly cash flow, I am a big fan of SPYI’s structure, as the monthly distributions are yielding close to 1%. As the risk-free rate of return declines, I think more investors will look toward SPYI to generate income, and I am bullish on its future potential.

data.title: Amphastar: Higher Costs, Lower Growth, And A 'Value Trap' Label
data.description:
Overview

My December 2025 evaluation of Amphastar Pharmaceuticals (AMPH) has come full circle after the company reported its Q4 earnings and FY26 expectations on Thursday.

This is a company undergoing a transition from "generic manufacturer plus one acquired brand" to a "proprietary pipeline." While laudable, it comes with growing pains. For one, Amphastar's branded products are having to grow in the shadow of its declining generic business-making YoY comps difficult.

While management was guiding FY26 for "high single-digit to low double-digit" revenue growth, I noted that "details were sparse, implying a good amount of modeling uncertainty."

I concluded that management's FY26 revenue guidance was "fragile" and recommended "caution" on its stock (maintain "Hold").

Amphastar's stock has dropped 20% in intraday trading Friday after lowering its FY26 revenue growth projection to the "mid- to high-single-digit range."

The paragraphs that follow revisit this biopharma in light of recent developments.

Earnings

Several things are happening at once-and most are bad.

Its legacy generic portfolio continues to plummet-faster than some had hoped. The legacy generic products continue to face intense "competitive pressure."

The kicker is revenue growth deceleration from branded products like BAQSIMI and Primatene MIST. In the US market, management will forgo a price increase this year, which signals that they are simply trying to steady BAQSIMI's volume. Management plans to pull BAQSIMI from certain international markets where it is unprofitable. When Amphastar acquired BAQSIMI from Eli Lilly (LLY), there was a 3-year mandate to support all markets. This mandate ends in July 2026. Until then, Amphastar is tasked with marketing BAQSIMI in unprofitable regions-negatively impacting its margins.

It sounds counterintuitive, but Amphastar's generic business was actually more profitable than its branded business.

Compare glucagon and BAQSIMI:

So these product mix trends (BAQSIMI takes up a growing portion of total revenues) have been negatively impacting Amphastar's margins as well.

Before late 2024, Amphastar's gross margins were consistently >50%. Then, of course, there are R&D and SG&A costs, which have had to ramp up due to pipeline investments and legal expenses, respectively. All of this together resulted in a 36% decrease in GAAP net income in Q4.

Now, these are all necessary pains required for Amphastar to evolve. So-so long as Amphastar is in a good place financially-the market's focus should be on the road ahead.

During the call, management clarified that the difference between "mid" and "high" single-digit growth in 2026 was pinned on AMP-007 (generic ipratropium). But as I talked about in December, AMP-007's best-case scenario (assuming no Authorized Generic joins the market) is a "short burst in revenues." The asset is not expected to be a major contributor beyond 2026/2027.

If you're looking for long-term major contributors for Amphastar, you have to direct your attention to its preclinical pipeline (acquired from Nanjing Anji last year). However, management admitted that they haven't even spoken to the FDA yet regarding AMP-110 (AMP-105, 107, 109, 110 are all proprietary pipeline programs).

And the big catalysts (a GLP-1 and insulin aspart) are not expected until 2027-leaving investors with not much to chew on until then besides stabilizing gross margins, increasing opex, an uncertain AMP-007 launch, and mid- to high-single-digit revenue growth.

Valuation Assumptions

On many metrics, AMPH screens "undervalued." On P/E GAAP (forward), AMPH's 7.85 trades at a ~58% discount to its sector peers.

When I play with my discounted cash flow model, I am mainly interested in finding out what AMPH is priced for, and then questioning how reasonable the implied growth/margin assumptions are.

For a company like Amphastar-that is transitioning from predictable generic products to novel drug development-it would likely not be wise to assume that it'll maintain its free cash flow margins of the past (~17% in the TTM). So, I modeled for 10% free cash flow margins and mid-single-digit growth (5%). These really represent averages over the nine-year projection period.

Now, single-point estimates can be a bit misleading. Just as there are multiple number that equal 100, there is a combination of free cash flow margin/revenue growth assumptions that would result in an equity value equal to AMPH's market value.

My Sensitivity Analysis (below) tells me that AMPH is 1.6x more sensitive to margins than growth.

Margin sensitivity is not something that should comfort Amphastar investors given recent trends and future expectations.

Thinking of different scenarios:

Maybe Amphastar is able to come close to its historical free cash flow margins and they hit the high-end of its FY26 revenue growth target ("Bull" scenario)?

Or maybe Amphastar, after another year or two, is truly approaching terminal growth and spinning their wheels with high R&D/SG&A spend ("Bear" scenario)?

I find the "Bear" scenario more likely-and possibly even optimistic over my nine-year projection-but it's hard to be too bearish on AMPH at these prices.

Final Words

In my experience, whenever a stock like AMPH appears "cheap," it's likely for good reasons. In this case, setting aside the present day growth and margin deceleration associated with its branded medicine transition, it feels the market is not confident in Amphastar's growth initiatives. And it's hard to blame them.

While BAQSMI margins may improve, "mid-single-digit unit growth" in the U.S. via increased S&M efforts doesn't excite me. AMP-007 (approved on February 24 with a launch planned for Q2) is merely an attempt to catch a "spark in a bottle." And generics like AMP-004 (insulin aspart) and AMP-018 (liraglutide) will likely face crowded and price-sensitive markets.

AMPH remains a cautious "Hold" and it is likely a "value trap" until management stumbles across a long-term solution to its growth problem.

data.title: QQQI: Buying The Nasdaq-100, But More Cautiously
data.description:
Investment Thesis

NEOS NASDAQ-100(R) High Income ETF (QQQI) is one of my favorite assets in my income-focused portfolio, one that I remain committed to and believe is worth buying. But the current US stock market is facing challenges from analysts and economists warning of a possible AI-driven crisis similar to the dot-com crash. As the composition of the QQQI portfolio is heavily dependent on the Mag-7, I aim to reassess the investment attractiveness of this ETF to determine whether it is appropriate to continue holding it given the current risks.

Fundamental concept of QQQI

QQQI is a fund that focuses on investing in the shares of the largest companies, the majority of which belong to the US technology sector (51.74% of the total portfolio weight). It is no surprise that the top holdings in the portfolio consist of Mag-7 companies, given that the ETF concept involves tracking the Nasdaq-100 index. There are 103 holdings in the portfolio, and the concentration is quite high, since the top 10 assets account for 48.83%. By tracking the index, this fund smooths out portfolio results but makes it impossible to get alpha from the growth of individual stocks.

Although the dividend yield is in the double digits at 14.30%, those managing QQQI are effectively balancing payouts and capital preservation, allowing for dividend yields without sacrificing capital growth. These payments are generated through an option strategy that uses index spreads (options are based on the Nasdaq-100 index rather than individual stocks). The mechanism of managing the option strategy QQQI involves a one-time sale of options and the use of a call spread, in which long call options are purchased in addition to the options already written. As a result, you get a profit from the net credit spread, the difference between the premium from selling call options and the cost of buying long call options on the out-of-the-money index.

I should also add that the QQQI option strategy (as with most of the NEOS family of ETFs) can generate payouts that are mostly in the form of return of capital. This means these payouts aren't considered income and aren't subject to immediate taxation, as well as reducing the cost basis when selling the ETF. Profits from QQQI fall under Section 1256, rendering it tax-efficient, since the premium is automatically classified on a 60/40 basis, where 60% of the income is taxed as long-term capital gains and 40% as short-term capital gains. In accordance with Form 8937, between January 2025 and June 2025, RoC accounted for 98.85% of all QQQI distributions, up from 94.45% between July 2024 and December 2024. The percentage of RoC distributions is influenced by the fact that it may indicate a decline in NAV over time; therefore, the high monthly RoC distributions should be viewed in relation to NAV dynamics.

As shown in the chart below, it is clear that QQQI is not an ETF that depletes capital. By way of example, an investor who invested $10,000 when the fund launched on January 29, 2024, has earned $4,307, compared to a return of only $3,240, or 24.8%, for an investment in the benchmark Nasdaq-100 Index. Taking into account the fund's two years of operation, that means the QQQI's return is on average 12.4% higher than the return from the benchmark. With capital erosion, you'd see QQQI's total return fall below the Nasdaq-100's return over time. That said, this fund's been around for two full years, so it's been around long enough to be considered a decent comparison to other option funds in the ETF market. That said, it's still too early to tell how QQQI will hold up over time, because it hasn't faced any major market downturns, for example, the pandemic. This means we don't have all the proof that the fund managers can keep the capital and overall returns going if the market goes into a serious bear market.

I suggest comparing QQQI with a passive fund, such as Invesco QQQ Trust (QQQ), in order to definitively determine the effectiveness of investing in QQQI. I took their total returns from January 29, 2024 (since QQQI was launched). In this period, total returns for QQQ were 1.79% higher than for QQQI. My view is that QQQ's results are higher during a bull market, and when the Nasdaq-100 moves into a sideways or bearish trend, it is likely that QQQI's actual results will be higher. Even though QQQI's net asset value will follow QQQ in the event of such a decline, its total return will be mitigated by the premium income received. In addition, it is worth considering when evaluating the effectiveness of investing in QQQI that this total return is mainly generated from dividend payments, a large part of which are paid in the form of RoC. For QQQ, overall returns are generated by capital growth. This means that when you factor in taxes on capital gains and dividends, you'll find that QQQI's real performance is way higher.

AI cycle stress test

Stress test results from the Federal Reserve for 2026 are alarming, since the worst-case scenario assumes a 54% stock market crash, mainly due to a crisis in the AI industry. The baseline scenario even assumes that over the next four years, average annual stock growth will be only 4.3%, signaling the end of the confident bull market. Furthermore, the volume of CDSs purchased by investors to hedge against such risks has increased to $10 billion (four times in one year). The largest volume of insurance through CDSs is recorded for Oracle ($6 billion), Amazon ($1.7 billion), Alphabet ($895 million), Meta Platforms ($687 million), and Microsoft ($521 million).

The main driver of the AI supercycle, Nvidia, has taken on a massive $95.2 billion commitment by signing contracts with semiconductor suppliers, ensuring full production capacity in the future. This is similar to what happened during the dot-com crash, where Cisco made similar purchases that led to huge inventories. Nvidia's main risk is that this bet on continued growth can only pay off if future demand for its products is as expected. In the opposite case, a huge inventory risk will render all CAPEX meaningless. Here's how CAPEX growth in 2026 compared to 2025 looks for the biggest hyperscalers.

Ultimately, the total CAPEX in 2026 will amount to approximately $750 billion, up $350 billion from 2025 and $510 billion from 2024. Nevertheless, one should bear in mind that the primary source of CAPEX financing is not profit, but long-term debt. Companies included in the Nasdaq-100 are increasing their credit leverage themselves, driven by the strategic need to quickly enter new AI sub-sectors. 2026 will see a continuation of the boom, with no room for a slow entry, since any delay in scaling up will result in the market being divided among investors who have invested more in development in a few years' time. It is precisely for this reason that the management of the largest IT giants continues to opt for increasing debt to finance CAPEX, and does not seek ways to optimize through self-financing. Even though the market is still wondering what the return on AI investments will be, because the infrastructure is being built today and the real ROI won't be known for a few years, the negative scenario will still take time to happen. For now, as the market momentum remains bullish, because monetization is beginning and margins remain unchanged, continue to bet on QQQI, the double-digit return of which now outweighs the potential risks from the uncertainty surrounding the Nasdaq-100.

Risks of the investment thesis

Investing in QQQI is still risky because it hasn't been tested in a really bearish market. For example, if the Nasdaq-100 drops more than 20-30% over 6-12 months, it's not clear how the fund's capital will hold up. This is because, under such circumstances, any premium generated by the option strategy is unlikely to cover more than half of the drawdown. In addition, it is precisely in such cases that further income generated may be reduced due to capital erosion, because the fund will have less capital to work with. Correspondingly, NAV decline could lead to even greater risks for investments in QQQI, thereby making it a less reliable ETF. One exception to this negative scenario could be that the bear market causes growth and market volatility, on which the size of the potential premium from selling options depends. Under such circumstances, profits generated from the option strategy may increase, improving the situation with NAV recovery. I would like to caution, though, in the event of a Nasdaq-100 reversal, the QQQI will definitely not be considered a hedging instrument against its decline, so it may be worth considering other assets.

Conclusion

As a result, even though analysts and economists are talking about more risks, it's still my opinion that the market won't crash in 2026 thanks to the massive CAPEX that's keeping the AI supercycle going. That is why I believe QQQI remains an attractive investment fund that targets double-digit dividend yields and offers tax optimization benefits. Nevertheless, from a long-term perspective, investors should exercise greater caution when maintaining income-oriented assets in their portfolios that are highly correlated with the performance of the Nasdaq-100 and Mag-7 stocks individually. That's why, should we encounter real data confirming unjustified demand for AI products and ROI from investments in data centers and network infrastructure, we'll be prepared to optimize the portfolio, which will most likely exclude ETFs such as QQQI.

data.title: Cal-Maine Foods Ended Up More Than I Thought It Would Crack Up To Be (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Acknowledging when you are wrong is one of the most important things, not only when it comes to investing, but when it comes to life in general. Being humble about your mistakes is how you learn and grow. A great example of this involving myself relates to my decision, back in April of 2022, to rate Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) a 'sell.' Leading up to that point, declining sales, profits, and cash flows, had dominated the financial narrative. Admittedly, the company was low risk because of its strong balance sheet. But the stock looked drastically overpriced. I underestimated, quite frankly, just what would happen in the egg market that the company operates in. I did not foresee prices skyrocketing because of industry supply constraints. That ultimately pushed revenue, profits, and cash flows, drastically higher. And as a result, the company's stock price has risen 81.9% at a time when the S&P 500 is up only 50.2%.

This was one of the biggest misses that I have had in the last couple of years. Looking at the picture today, I see a company that is continuing to benefit from elevated prices. But make no mistake that these price increases are likely temporary. Data from the USDA suggests that prices will drop throughout 2026. And in fact, for the 2026 fiscal year for the company, we have already seen a deleterious impact on the bottom line as a result. Having said that, the stock is incredibly cheap right now. And its balance sheet is remarkably robust. I wouldn't go so far as to upgrade the stock to a 'buy' because of worries over declining prices. But I do think that rating it a very solid 'hold' makes sense here.

The picture is better than I thoughts

Some companies in the food industry are incredibly diverse from an operational standpoint. And others, such as Cal-Maine Foods, are much more concentrated. The company prides itself on being the largest producer and distributor of shell eggs in the US. Its operations consist of hatching chicks, growing and maintaining flocks of pullets, dealing with layers and breeders, producing feed, and ultimately producing and distributing eggs. The company is massive in this industry. According to management, the fleet as of the end of the most recent quarter consisted of 11.4 million pullets and breeders, as well as 49.3 million layers.

Over the last few years, financial performance for the business has been admittedly mixed. In the chart above, you can see financial results for the 2023 through 2025 fiscal years. Revenue has certainly been lumpy. And profits and cash flows have responded in kind. What matters most, however, is that in 2025, the company achieved significant revenue that far exceeded what it had achieved in prior fiscal years. In the chart below, you can see results for the first half of the 2026 fiscal year compared to the same time of 2025. In this case, revenue, profits, and most cash flow metrics, pulled back.

These results have changed a lot, based primarily on changes in egg prices. You see, the vast majority of the company's revenue, approximately 85% for the first half of 2026, came specifically from the sale of shell eggs. Normally when you see rapid revenue growth like what was experienced over the last couple of years, it's because of continued investments aimed at boosting output. Yes, the company has achieved some expansion on that front. From 2023 through 2025, the firm went from selling 1.15 billion dozens of eggs to selling 1.28 billion dozens of eggs. And for the first half of 2026, the 640.2 million dozens of eggs produced by the company exceeded the 639.8 million dozen reported the previous year.

The bigger expansion for the company came from a hike in average prices for shell eggs. Back in 2023, prices averaged $2.62 per dozen. That dropped to $1.93 in 2024 before surging to $3.13 last year. Unfortunately, an outbreak of bird flu drastically slashed supplies of layers in the space. According to one source, since 2022, tens of millions of commercial egg layers have been impacted. This naturally caused a decline in overall supply, while demand remained robust. After all, eggs still remain a major source of protein at an affordable price. So when alternative options are still more expensive, demand remains resilient. We have started to see prices decline. In the first half of the 2026 fiscal year, they dropped to $2.25 per dozen. That's down from the $2.57 per dozen reported a year earlier.

The company also continues to benefit from expansion elsewhere. Even though the production and sale of shell eggs represents the main source of revenue growth for the company, it is investing heavily into the egg products and prepared foods markets. Examples here include hard-cooked eggs, egg wraps, protein pancakes, crepes, and wrap-ups. In that vein, in September of 2024, the company made an investment in Crepini LLC, essentially establishing a new egg products and prepared foods joint venture. And in the 2025 fiscal year, the business acquired Echo Lake Foods in a deal valued at $258 million. That business, based out of Wisconsin, produces, packages, markets, and distributes, prepared foods such as waffles, pancakes, scrambled eggs, frozen cooked omelets, egg patties, toast, and diced eggs.

These activities have helped to boost revenue for the prepared foods and egg products spaces as of late. Prior to the 2026 fiscal year, management never broke out these two separate categories. In the chart above, you can see expansion in revenue for them combined over the last two fiscal years. And in the chart below, you can see revenue figures for them when it comes to the first half of 2026 compared to the first half of 2025. Although this is great to see, it's not going to represent the largest portion of the company and its health. A lot will still depend on shell egg production and prices associated with them.

If we project out results for the company based on what was seen in the first half of 2026, we would expect net profits for the fiscal year to be around $998.8 million. Adjusted operating cash flow would be $1.25 billion, while EBITDA would amount to $1.38 billion. Using these estimates, and also the results that the company achieved for the 2025 fiscal year, we can see in the chart below how the stock is priced at the moment. Honestly, these are incredibly low multiples. And compared to other companies that are in the food space, which the chart below illustrates, the stock is definitely the cheapest of the group. Add on top of this the fact that it has a net cash position of $1.14 billion compared to a market capitalization of only $3.96 billion, and we are looking at an incredibly healthy company trading on the cheap.

Normally in cases like this, I would be incredibly bullish. In fact, I would typically be buying the stock hand over fist. However, I am concerned about prices moving forward. After seeing table eggs drop from 7.74 billion pounds in 2024 to 7.37 billion pounds in 2025, which would be a decline of 4.8% year over year, it's expected, according to the USDA, for overall egg production to shoot up to 7.90 billion pounds in the US this year. Prices are forecasted to fall drastically.

Grade A large eggs, for instance, should see prices drop from $3.74 per dozen last year to $1.20 per dozen this year. That will absolutely have an impact on the bottom line results for the company and likely means that the valuation data that I applied for 2026 is higher than what will ultimately be achieved. Of course, even if profits and cash flows are cut by half, we are still looking at a company that is attractively priced. But because of the uncertainty that exists here, I think a more cautious approach to valuing the company is warranted.

One thing that will work in the company's favor as time goes on is that management continues to make investments in transforming the operation. I already talked about its move into the egg products and prepared foods space. But that's not all. Within the shell egg category, for instance, the company continues to transition away from conventional eggs and towards specialty ones. In the second quarter of 2026, 44% of shell egg sales were specialty eggs. That's up from 32% a year earlier. This is important because, in addition to experiencing higher demand, specialty eggs also demand higher prices. Take the second quarter of the 2026 fiscal year as an example. During that quarter, conventional shell egg prices averaged $1.80 per dozen. That was down drastically from the $2.94 per dozen reported the previous year. But year over year, specialty egg prices dropped only slightly from $2.39 per dozen to $2.37 per dozen.

Management is making organic investments into the prepared foods side of the business also. In fact, the company recently launched a $15 million network optimization and capacity expansion project aimed at adding 17 million pounds annually of scrambled eggs production by the middle of the 2027 fiscal year. And on top of this, it's also investing $14.8 million into its high-speed pancake line. If everything goes according to plan, this should boost capacity for that product line by 12 million pounds through early fiscal 2027. When you add on top of this the fact that the aforementioned joint venture, Crepini Foods, will see the company invest $7 million through the 2028 fiscal year to add 18 million pounds of capacity, we are looking at significant capacity growth over the next couple of years.

Management also continues to focus on returning capital to shareholders. In fact, the company is currently paying out about a third of all net profits to the investor base in the form of dividends. The company also has a $500 million share buyback program in place. And in the first half of the 2026 fiscal year, the company bought back 846,037 shares in exchange for $74.8 million. That leaves $375.2 million remaining under its buyback initiative.

Takeaway

Based on all the data provided, I must say that I am definitely intrigued by Cal-Maine Foods right now. The company is certainly a high-quality business with very little in the way of solvency or liquidity risk. In fact, it is remarkably stable. I like seeing the investments being made by management. Diversifying away from conventional eggs is certainly a wise idea, especially considering their commoditized nature and volatility. Because of how cheap the stock is, it's difficult not to be bullish. But I do think that, based on the picture and its totality, the company deserves a very solid 'hold' rating. It would be higher if not for worries over declining egg prices. But for now, a more cautious approach is justified.

data.title: 10 Best CEFs This Month: Average Yield Of 9.7% (February 2026)
data.description:
Introduction:

Since Nov. 2025, the market has been mostly trading in a tight range between S&P 500 (SPX) levels 6600 and 6950. However, the S&P500 did cross the SPX7000 level briefly in January, but it has not done so in any meaningful way. There have been so many developments in the last month or so, ranging from cooling inflation, the Fed holding interest rates steady, the tariff situation in light of the Supreme Court order, and the evolving geopolitical situation around Iran. On top of that, the AI overvaluations and overborrowing have gripped the markets for some time. Also, fear of the AI impacts on software stocks has resulted in brutal revaluations and may be overdone. The outperformance of the foreign markets (over the U.S. market) and rotation of big money from technology to industrial, materials, energy, and utility sectors is continuing.

The further progress and direction of the market may also depend on the actions of the Fed. You can see the current odds of the Fed's next rate cut here on the CME FedWatchTool website.

All that being said, it is always hard to find anything that has both the quality and the low valuation, so buying the best of the income investments regularly in small quantities is the key. As always, investors have to tread carefully amid all the uncertainties.

Why CEFs?

The broader market, as represented by the S&P500, provides a dismal level of yield of less than 1.10%. Income investors and retirees can't survive on that level of income unless they have a very large pool of capital. Also, the method of raising income by selling shares is generally very stressful and full of pitfalls, and that's why it is not recommended. Alternatively, one can find solid blue-chip individual dividend stocks that pay much higher dividends than the S&P 500. They can also provide market-matching growth on a longer-term basis. To identify such stocks, we also publish a monthly article on the '5 Best DGI stocks'. You can find the most recent one here.

However, with CEFs, we can take the income to the next level. That said, they generally come with higher risks (discussed later), so we believe that an allocation of 20% to 30% to a diversified CEF portfolio should be good enough for most income investors. In summary, these investments should be used primarily for income, not growth.

We publish this monthly article on CEFs (Closed-end funds) to provide our readers with a select list of 10 CEFs that, as a group, provide wide diversification in terms of underlying assets, solid long-term performance at least on a relative basis, and are trading at decent valuations. Above all, the income goal for the group is to provide a yield of at least 8% or higher.

This month, as a group, the selected 10 best funds are offering an average distribution rate of 8.70% (as of 01/16/2026). Besides excellent distributions, these funds have had an excellent record over the long term and collectively returned 17.7%, 12.2%, and 13.3% (annualized) in the last three, five years, and 10 years, respectively. The average discount (to NAV) is attractive, at -7.5%. Since this is a monthly series, some selections may overlap from month to month.

Why Is It Important To Have A Diversified CEF Portfolio?

We believe a well-diversified CEF portfolio should contain at least 10 CEFs, preferably from different asset classes. It's also advisable to build the portfolio over a period rather than invest in one lump sum. If you were to invest in one CEF every month for a year, you would have a well-diversified CEF portfolio by the year's end. What we provide here every month is a list of ten probable candidates for further research. A CEF portfolio can be an important component of the overall portfolio strategy. One should preferably have a DGI portfolio as the foundation, and the CEF portfolio could be used to boost the income level to the desired level. How much should one allocate to CEFs? Each investor needs to answer this question himself/herself based on their personal situation and factors like the size of the portfolio, income needs, risk appetite, or risk tolerance.

Criteria to Shortlist:

Criteria

Brings down the number of funds to...

Reason for the Criteria

Baseline expense < 2.5% and Avg. Daily Volume > 10,000

Approx. 435 Funds

We do not want funds that charge excessive fees. Also, we want funds that have fair liquidity.

Market capitalization> 100 Million

Approx. 400 Funds

We do not want funds that are too small.

Track record/ History longer than five years (inception date 2016 or earlier)

Approx. 375 Funds

We want funds that have a reasonably long track record.

Discount/Premium < +7%

Approx. 350 Funds

We do not want to pay too high a premium; we want bigger discounts.

Distribution (dividend) Rate > 5%

Approx. 250-290 Funds

The current distribution (income) is reasonably high.

5-Year Annualized Return on NAV > 0% AND/ OR

3-Year Annualized Return on NAV >0%

Approx. 200-250 Funds

We want funds with a reasonably good past track record in maintaining their NAVs.

After we applied the above criteria this month, we are generally left with around 250 funds (plus or minus 5%) on our list. From here on, we apply our other criteria to narrow the list.

Note: All tables in this article have been created by the author (unless explicitly specified). Most of the data in this article is sourced from Cefconnect.com, Cefa.com, and Morningstar.com.

Narrowing Down To 50 Funds:

To narrow down the number of funds to a more manageable count, we will shortlist ten funds based on each of the following criteria. Thereafter, we will apply certain qualitative criteria to each fund and rank them to select the top five.

At this stage, we also eliminate certain funds with substantially negative NAV returns for both three-year and five-year periods.

Seven Broad Criteria:

  • Excess discount/premium (explained below).
  • Distribution rate.
  • Return on NAV, last three years (medium-term).
  • Return on NAV, last five years (long term).
  • Coverage ratio.
  • Excess return over distributions.
  • The total weight (calculated up to this point).

Excess Discount/Premium

We certainly like funds that are offering large discounts (not premiums) to their NAVs. But what's important is to look at the "excess discount/premium" and not the absolute value. We want to see the discount (or premium) relative to their past record, say, a 52-week average.

Excess Discount/Premium = Current Discount/Premium (Minus) 52-Wk Avg. Discount/ Premium.

For more explanation of the excess discount and z-scores, please refer to our blog post (link provided at the beginning of the article).

We sort our list (of approx. 250 funds) on the "excess discount/premium" in descending order. For this criterion, the lower the value, the better it is. So, we select the top 10 funds (with the most negative values) from this sorted list.

(All data as of 02/20/2026)

Table 1:

High Current Distribution Rate

After all, most investors invest in CEF funds for their juicy distributions. Even though we should not chase yield, at this stage, we want to give them a fair representation in our list and subject them to a more rigorous criterion later on. We sorted our list on the current distribution rate (descending order, highest at the top) and selected the top 10 funds from this sorted list.

Table 2:

Medium-Term Return on NAV (last three years)

We then sort our list on a three-year return on NAV (in descending order, highest at the top) and select the top 10 funds. For this reason, we make a shortlist based on the total score and keep only a few of them on this list.

Table 3:

Five-Year Annualized Return on NAV

We then sorted our list on the five-year return on NAV (in descending order, highest at the top) and selected the top 10 funds.

Table 4:

Coverage Ratio (Distributions Vs. Earnings)

The coverage ratio is derived by dividing the earnings per share by the distribution amount for a specific period. Please note that in some cases, the coverage ratio may be a bit inaccurate since the "earnings per share" may be three to six months old. But in most cases, it's fairly accurate. Furthermore, the coverage ratio is not critical for pure equity funds as they generate very little dividend income, and they cover most of their distributions from capital gains. However, we sorted our list by coverage ratio and selected the top 10 funds.

Table 5:

Excess Return Over Distribution

If a fund provides a very high distribution but low returns over 3, 5, or 10-year periods, it does not help the long-term interests of the investor. In simple terms, the fund is just overpaying the distributions and hurting the NAV in the long term. That is why we calculate a factor we like to call "excess return." This excess return is what is provided by the fund over and above the distribution rate over a specified time period. We calculate it by subtracting the distribution rate from the average of the three-year and five-year NAV returns. In this list, we included the top 10 funds.

Table 6:

Total Weight (Quality Score) Calculated Up to This Point

Note: The Total Weight calculation is not fully completed at this point since we have not considered the 10-year NAV return. However, we select the top 15 names based on current calculations.

Table 7:

From the selections so far, we have 75 funds in total (tables 1-7).

We will need to see if there are any duplicates among them. In our current list of 75 funds, there were 26 duplicates, meaning there are funds that appeared more than once. The following names appear twice (or more):

Appeared twice: AIO, BANX, BGR, BRW, EDF, EMF, EOD, JCE, PDT, SRV, UTF, and XFLT (12 duplicates).

Appeared three times: CSQ, EMO, EOS, GAM, PDX, and TWN (12 duplicates).

Appeared four times: EIC, GGN (6 duplicates).

Once we remove 30 duplicate rows, we are left with 45 (75- 30) funds.

Note: It may be worthwhile to mention here that just because a fund has appeared multiple times does not necessarily make it an attractive candidate. Sometimes, a fund may appear multiple times simply for the wrong reasons, like a high current discount, a high excess discount, or a very high distribution rate that may not be sustainable. However, during the second filtering stage, it may not score well on the overall quality score due to other factors, like a poor track record. That said, if a fund has appeared four times or more, it may be worth a second look.

Narrowing Down to Just 10 Funds:

In our list of funds, we may already have some of the best probable candidates. However, so far, they have been selected based on one (or two) criteria that each may be good at. That's not nearly enough. So, we will apply a combination of criteria by applying weights to eight factors to calculate the total quality score and filter out the best ones.

We will apply weights to each of the eight criteria:

Criteria

Max. Weight

Comment

Baseline expense

5.0

Current distribution rate

7.5

Excess discount/premium

5.0

3-YR NAV return

5.0

5-YR NAV return

5.0

10-YR NAV return or 10-YR Total return

5.0

If less than ten years of history, an average of three and five-year returns is taken.

Excess NAV return over distribution rate

5.0

Adjusted Coverage Ratio

7.5

This factor is adjusted for certain factors. The adjustment is performed based on the type of fund, such as equity and sector funds.

Once we have calculated the weights, we combine them to calculate the "Total Combined Weight," also called the "Quality Score."

The sorted list (spreadsheet) of 45 funds on the "combined total weight or quality score" is attached here.

File-for-export_-_10_Best_CEFs_-_Feb_2026.xlsx

10-Positions Portfolio of The Month:

Before we get to the final ten, we will narrow down our list to 20 names. So, we sorted our table based on the sector and then the quality score. Furthermore, in this round of selections, we mostly pick one or two top funds from each sector (based on quality score). There is a bit of subjective judgment, as we tend to prioritize funds that pay regular and consistent distributions on a monthly or quarterly basis. We also weed out any fund that may have a very poor track record in terms of NAV performance. Funds that may have inconsistent dividends (even if they are high) generally do not make it to our top list. Furthermore, be aware that many times, single-country funds score high in our rankings, but most of them pay variable dividends on an annual or semi-annual basis. In addition, being single-country funds, they can be inherently riskier since their future returns are tied to just one country, be it economic, regulatory, or geopolitical factors. For these reasons, they generally do not make it to our top 5 lists, but they do appear on our list of 20. Individual investors could consider them based on their goals.

Here's the list of the top 20 selections (from different asset classes) in the order of sector:

Table 8:

10-Best-CEFs of the Month

In the end, if we only want to select ten funds, we will need to apply our subjective judgment to some degree. While we narrow down this list to ten names, we would be mindful to keep the list as diversified as possible in terms of sectors and asset classes. Since this step is somewhat subjective, the choice would differ from person to person. Nonetheless, here are the selections for this month, based on our perspective (in order of Quality Score):

Here's the list of the top 10 selections this month (in order of sector):

(EOS), (SCD), (JRI), (EOD), (EIC), (AIO), (UTF), (PEO), (HQL), and (GAM).

Table-9:

Some information about the selections:

We will only briefly describe the selected funds. Since there are 10 of them, we will not be providing a very detailed analysis of them.

Here are some details on many of our selections:

(EOS) Eaton Vance Enhanced Equity Income II:

When it comes to covered call funds, it is hard to beat Eaton Vance funds. Also, EOS is one of the best funds in its category. Its high exposure to the technology sector has definitely helped the fund to shine in the last 10 years. It currently holds only about 50 companies and overwrites (sells options) on roughly 50% of its portfolio to generate income and reduce volatility. The distribution yield is attractive at 8.3%, and currently offers a decent discount of -6%. The fund uses no leverage, and its expenses are comparable to those of its competitors. The past performance record is solid, and it has returned 22%, 11%, and 14% (annualized) over the last 3, 5, and 10-year periods.

(SCD) LMP Capital and Income

SCD is a fairly diversified fund invested in equity as well as fixed-income securities from many sectors. However, nearly 73% of the assets are in equity stocks from many sectors.

The fund is categorized under "Global Allocation," but over 85% is invested in U.S. securities. Broadly, the current allocation is as follows:

  • 73% Common Stocks, mostly US-based, with 16% Financials, 14% Technology, 12% Industrial, 12% Energy, and 8% Healthcare
  • 7.6% MLPs
  • 7% Preferred/Convertible
  • 6% Equity REITs
  • 3.5% Bonds.

The yield is attractive at 9% plus, and the current discount is -8%.

(JRI) Nuveen Real Asset Income & Growth Fund

The fund JRI is a global fund offered by the Nuveen group. It invests in real asset-related companies, including equity stocks, preferred, and debt securities. Real asset-related investments could include companies that are engaged in owning, developing, or operating infrastructure projects or facilities, as well as REITs. Nearly 50-55% of the assets are invested in the U.S.-based companies. The fund uses a significant amount of leverage (roughly 30%) and is very well diversified with nearly 450 holdings. The investments are roughly 45%:55% in real estate vs infrastructure.

The fund has just announced a rights offering, and that is one reason that the discount has widened to nearly -8%. The yield is attractive at 12% plus.

(AIO) Virtus AI & Tech Opp Fund:

This is a fund focused on AI (Artificial Intelligence) and technology companies. But it comes with a unique flavor of combining both the equity and convertible securities, as well as some bonds, based on market conditions. The fund also uses modest leverage of roughly 12% and has performed very well in the last three years. It provides a decent distribution yield of just under 8% and is currently trading at an attractive discount of roughly -10%. This fund was included in December/January as well, but recently the price has come under pressure, and the discount has widened somewhat.

(EIC) Eagle Point Income Co:

EIC is probably the riskiest fund in this selection of 10 funds. The fund uses high leverage of 32% in the form of preferred stock. The fund primarily invests in junior debt tranches of CLOs (Collateralized Loan Obligations). In addition, it may invest up to 35% of total assets in CLO equity securities and related securities.

Due to the decline in interest rates, similar to its peers, the fund has been reducing its distribution amount. The monthly distribution has come down from $0.20 a share to $0.11, a 45% reduction. This has caused the price to fall during most of 2025, and that has continued in 2026, but the pace has slowed down. So, it has been brutal for someone who acquired the shares prior to 2024. However, the yield is still very attractive for the new buyers at 13.2%, in spite of the lower distribution amount. The discount has widened to very high levels at -24%. With reduced distribution, the current distribution is fully covered by the NII (net investment income). However, on a full nine-month basis (January to September), it only covered to the extent of 75%, as the distribution was much higher at the beginning of last year. We think that after significant correction, the price and yield are attractive. However, it is quite likely that the distribution amount may further fall if the interest rates decline further, so this fund should only be accumulated in multiple lots on a dollar-cost-average basis.

(EOD) Allspring Global Dividend Opportunity Fund:

The international funds of all types have done well during the year 2025, and that trend is continuing in 2026. This fund is selected to provide exposure to global equity as well as fixed income. The fund is invested roughly 80% in global equities with a focus on dividends, and the rest in fixed income (18%) and cash equivalents (2%). The equity portion is invested in 70-80 companies spread across many sectors and segments. The fund also employs an options strategy on a portion of the equity portfolio to enhance income and to generate gains on call options. The fund also uses a modest leverage of just under 15%.

The allocation to the U.S. is roughly 65% of the total, and the rest is invested in countries such as the U.K., France, Japan, China, Germany, Italy, Canada, Taiwan, and Brazil. The largest sector is information Technology at 25%, followed by Financials and Communications.

The yield is decent at 8.5%, and the discount is close to -8%.

(UTF) Cohen & Steers Infrastructure Fund:

This is one of the most popular Utility and Infrastructure funds out there in the CEF space, besides the Reaves Utility Income fund (UTG). However, UTF appears to offer better value currently compared to UTG, even though both have appreciated quite a bit in the last 12 months.

The fund invests in infrastructure companies, which consist of utilities, pipelines, toll roads, airports, railroads, ports, and telecommunications companies. The fund offers a close to 7% yield and a discount of roughly -7%. The fund offers a very reliable distribution payout as it has paid consistent and growing distributions since its inception.

(PEO) Adams Natural Resources Fund:

If you like to own some of the large-cap energy majors at a discount, you can't beat the PEO fund offered by the Adams group. It is a very nice fund to hold the energy majors, and that too at good discounts (currently hovering around -9%). This fund provides a diversified exposure to large energy companies. At the same time, there is some over-concentration at the top, given the fact that the two oil majors, Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), together represent nearly 38% of the total assets. The yield has come down somewhat in recent months, but it is still attractive at it 7.5%. Please keep in mind that this is an energy sector-specific fund, and hence, one should allocate accordingly.

(HQL) abrdn Life Sciences Investors

The fund had not done too well in recent years, from 2022 to 2024. However, the fund has recovered in the last year and gained roughly 23% in the previous 12 months, excluding nearly 13% dividends.

The fund recently increased the distribution amounts, and the distribution yield is very attractive at 13.35%. It also offers a discount of -8.7%.

The fund uses almost zero leverage and invests in well-known names from the biotechnology sector. This fund has managed to pay a consistent distribution, but mostly from the capital gains and, to some extent, ROC (return of capital).

Some of the top holdings are Amgen (AMGN), Vaxcyte (PCVX), UniQure NV (QURE), Insmed Inc (INSM), Regeneron (REGN), Gilead (GILD), Vertex (VRTX), and BioMarin (BMRN).

(GAM) General American Investors:

GAM is our selection for the core U.S. equity fund for this month. It should be noted that the fund pays annually in the month of December, and the payment is variable from one year to another. Based on the distribution paid in December 2025, the yield is quite attractive at over 10%. The current discount is close to -11%. Income investors who like to have regular quarterly (or monthly) distributions should look elsewhere.

The primary investment objective of the fund is to seek capital appreciation, with income only a secondary objective. The fund invests in equity securities with growth potential at reasonable valuations. The fund also uses a modest leverage in the form of preferred stock.

CEF-Specific Investment Risks:

It goes without saying that CEFs generally have some additional risks. This section is specifically relevant for investors who are new to CEF investing, but in general, all CEF investors should be aware of it. For more details on these specific risks, please read our blog post on CEFs.

  • Use of high leverage and high fees
  • High volatility (compared to the broader market)
  • Premium over NAVs (market price higher than the NAV)
  • Asset-specific concentration risk.

Concluding Thoughts:

The broader market, as represented by the S&P500, provides a dismal yield of less than 1.20%. Many income investors and retirees can't survive on that kind of income. For income investors, we recommend building a core bucket of DGI (Dividend growth) stocks and supplementing it with a basket of CEFs to increase the overall income.

We use our screening process to highlight the best closed-end funds for investment each month. Our filtering process demands that our selections have an above-average long-term performance record, offer an average of roughly 8% distributions, and are relatively cheaper with reasonable discounts. We have also provided a larger list of ten CEFs from many different asset classes.

This month, as a group, the selected 10 best funds are offering an average distribution rate of 8.70% (as of 01/16/2026). Besides excellent distributions, these funds have had an excellent record over the long term and collectively returned 17.7%, 12.2%, and 13.3% (annualized) in the last three, five years, and 10 years, respectively. The average discount (to NAV) is attractive, at -7.5%. Since this is a monthly series, some selections may overlap from month to month.

Please note that these selections are based on our proprietary rating system and are dynamic in nature. So, they can change from month to month (or even week to week). At the same time, some funds can repeat from one month to the next if they remain attractive over an extended period. Furthermore, note that if a fund has not made it to our list, it does not mean it is not good. It could be because they may not be attractively priced at this time or trading at a premium while running our filtering process.

data.title: Marsh & McLennan Companies: New Name, Same Great Company
data.description:
Co-authored by Kody's Dividends

When we look at the American economy, we're so used to thinking about the major brands.

When you think about soda, you may initially think about just Coca-Cola (KO) and Pepsi (PEP), failing to realize that there are hundreds of smaller local or regional brands that exist. Jones Soda, for example, is a smaller brand that's not publicly traded. However, big brands often devour or buy out smaller brands, bringing them into their larger portfolio. This can cause concentration in sectors into some large names, even though they may have hundreds of smaller names that feed revenue upwards to the mothership. For years, you could buy Canada Dry or Schweppes Ginger Ale, and you were supporting a local brand versus a much larger one. However, Keurig Dr. Pepper (KDP) bought both of these companies in the past few decades.

Other sectors remain highly segmented as well. Convenience store ownership is still primarily a mom-and-pop segment, with the vast majority of store owners owning fewer than 5 locations.

It may surprise many readers that the insurance market is among these highly segmented sectors as well. Larger firms can grow through organic growth as well as buying smaller, well-performing peers as bolt-on acquisitions.

Today, I want to zero in on a company doing just that.

Let's dive in!

Combining Organic Growth With Savvy Acquisitions

Last month, the company changed its brand identity from Marsh & McLennan Companies, or MMC to Marsh (MRSH) (though Marsh & McLennan Companies remains the legal entity name). MRSH is an insurance broker and advisory company.

For an idea of its size, the company's total revenue in 2025 was nearly $27 billion, and it advised clients in approximately 130 countries. MRSH closed out 2025 with strong momentum, too.

Its revenue grew by 8.7% year-over-year to $6.60 billion in the fourth quarter. That beat Seeking Alpha's analyst consensus by $50 million for the period. Much of this growth was powered by its acquisition of McGriff Insurance Services, with its underlying businesses delivering the remaining 4% of topline growth during the quarter.

MRSH's adjusted EPS rose by 9.8% over the year-ago period to $2.12 in the fourth quarter. This topped the analyst consensus for the quarter by $0.15. Because the company gained leverage from its revenue growth, adjusted operating margin expanded by about 40 basis points to 23.7% during the quarter. That's how adjusted EPS growth outpaced revenue growth in the quarter.

Looking ahead, MRSH has a few levers to pull to keep growing.

For one, the company should be able to maintain a mid-single-digit annual organic revenue growth rate. This is because, as the economy grows, businesses have more assets to insure. As an insurance broker, MRSH's cut also grows over time.

Additionally, the company is a frequent player in the M&A space. MRSH's A- S&P credit rating with a stable outlook provides it with the low cost of capital and flexibility to further consolidate a very fragmented industry.

Finally, the deployment of agentic AI and productivity tools can automate high-volume tasks, like policy checking and Certificates of Insurance. This is how MRSH can grow its revenue at a faster rate than expenses, which produces margin expansion over time.

For these reasons, the FAST Graphs analyst consensus is for adjusted EPS to grow by 7.7% annually through 2028, off a 2025 base of $9.75.

MRSH offers a 2% dividend yield. Considering that the adjusted EPS payout ratio is set to be in the mid-30% range for 2026, the payout appears to be quite sustainable. That positions it to build on its 16-year dividend growth streak with more annual dividend growth in the 9% to 10% range. This would work out to a respectable Chowder number in the range of 11 to 12.

MRSH is a compelling value. At the current $181 share price, the stock is trading at a forward 12-month P/E ratio of 18.39. This is far less than the FAST Graphs 10-year average P/E ratio of 21.9.

However, we believe that a realistic fair value P/E ratio for MRSH in the coming years is closer to 20. That's because its high single-digit annual percentage adjusted EPS growth consensus is somewhat lower than the 10-year CAGR of 12.3%. This produces a fair value per share estimate of $210, which indicates MRSH's shares are priced at a 19% discount to fair value.

If it meets growth forecasts and reverts to fair value, it could log a 16% total return through 2026. By the end of 2031, the insurance brokerage firm could have a path to 11% annual total returns.

Key risks facing MRSH include AI disruption in the insurance brokerage space and property catastrophe pricing headwinds.

The launch of a new AI tool by Insurify recently caused a further selloff in insurance brokerage stocks. The fear is that AI could automate the middleman roles in insurance, which could compress the margins of MRSH.

While this is a very real long-term risk, we believe that it's somewhat mitigated by the complex nature of MRSH's policies that require more subjective negotiations. Still, it's worth watching for future developments.

Another risk to MRSH is that President and CEO John Doyle flagged softening in the property cat market as reinsurers are pursuing growth by deploying more capital on the Q4 2025 Earnings Call. After years of strength in this market, pricing declines could somewhat reduce MRSH's growth.

Conclusion

MRSH offers the opportunity to investors to own shares of a strong company that is actively expanding its market share through organic growth and acquisitions. It can effectively leverage its size and credit rating to tap into inexpensive debt, which helps fuel higher returns on their actions.

The insurance sector has been heavily sold off over AI fears, while much of the rest of the market has been selling off AI companies over the fear that they're not going to be able to produce strong returns from the massive amount of capital that they're spending on development.

This has created deep value opportunities all over the sector, and MRSH is one of them.

data.title: Duolingo: This High-Quality Business Remains Deeply Misunderstood By The Market
data.description:
Introduction

Duolingo (DUOL) trades on a 10% free cash flow yield and its cheapest valuation since IPO despite:

  1. Dominant global market share
  2. 35% free cash flow margins in 2025
  3. Consistent double-digit revenue growth
  4. A pristine balance sheet with over $1b net cash
  5. Multiple emerging growth verticals like chess and maths

The market is pricing Duolingo as a structurally impaired business facing AI-driven disruption and terminal growth deceleration.

In my view, the market is taking an extremely short-term view on near-term headwinds and overestimating the risk of terminal disruption to Duolingo. Despite recent share price volatility, Duolingo remains a structurally advantaged consumer subscription business with a capital-light business model, world-class founder, and long-term growth runway.

A High-Quality Consumer Franchise

Duolingo is the clear global leader in language learning apps, with approximately 85% market share of paid subscribers worldwide. This position was earned through product-led growth, consistent R&D investment, and organic product growth, not financial engineering or acquisition-driven expansion.

Since its IPO in 2021, Duolingo has delivered exceptional operating performance:

  • DAUs: 10.1m → 52.7m (51% CAGR)
  • Paid subscribers: 2.5m → 12.2m (49% CAGR)
  • Revenue: $251m → $1.04bn (43% CAGR)
  • Gross margins: Sustained between 72-73%
  • Free cash flow margin: 5% → 35%

Few public companies have compounded both growth and profitability at this level.

Why the Market is Wrong

1 – AI is More Likely to Strengthen Duolingo Than Disrupt It

The prevailing bear thesis on Duolingo is that generative AI will disintermediate language learning apps.

The data does not support this view.

First, retention metrics remain stable across cohorts.

I mean retention, it looks pretty flat over a fairly long period of time. And we look at it in aggregate, and we look at it via cohorts. I think the perspective we have is that it can stay where it is. (Duolingo CFO, Q4 2025 Earnings Call)

Second, paid subscriber growth remains strong (28% growth in their latest quarter), and the DAU/MAU ratio (a measure of user engagement) hit an all-time high of 40% in 2025.

Third, marketing spend as a percentage of revenue remained stable at 12% from 2024 to 2025, which suggests no deterioration in customer acquisition efficiency.

If AI were meaningfully disrupting Duolingo, it would show up in churn, engagement, or marketing efficiency metrics.

More importantly, the AI disruption bear narrative misunderstands Duolingo’s core value proposition. Duolingo is not simply a content provider—their edge lies in their behavioural engagement. Effective skill acquisition (e.g., learning a language or chess) requires:

  • Structured progression
  • Reinforcement loops
  • Habit formation
  • Accountability mechanisms

Duolingo's core competitive advantage is consumer engagement using tools like daily streaks, leagues, gamification loops, and humorous avatars. Generic AI chat interfaces do not replicate these behavioural tools.

Real-time language translation via earphones could have an impact over the medium-to-long term, but such devices have been available for years with minimal discernible impact on Duolingo’s business. The CEO addressed this exact concern in their latest earnings call:

So AI translation isn’t – people talk about it, but it is not something that we are worried internally about. AI translation has been essentially perfect among the largest languages for like more than 10 years. I mean between Spanish and English, it’s essentially been perfect. Our users use Duolingo for 2 main reasons: one, as a hobby, they actually want to learn. And those people, whether there’s AI translation, it doesn’t matter, it’s a hobby for them. And then the other group of people is learning English. They want to learn English, and they actually want to learn English. We know also that we ask users why they leave Duolingo. We have this churn user surveys. This [AI translation] does not come up. (Duolingo CEO, Q4 2025 Earnings Call)

My view is that AI enhances Duolingo’s competitive position via:

  1. Lower marginal cost of content creation
  2. Faster expansion into new languages and subjects
  3. Improved user personalisation

With 133m MAUs and more than a decade of proprietary longitudinal data, Duolingo is much better positioned than competitors to integrate AI into their app at scale. Smaller competitors simply lack the user base, longitudinal data, and balance sheet to deploy AI as efficiently as Duolingo.

2 – Duolingo is Not Ex-Growth

The second bear narrative is myopically focused on the recent growth slowdown and 2026 guidance. Bookings and MAU growth undeniably moderated in H2 2025 – bookings growth decelerated from 38% in Q1 2025 to 24% in Q4 2025, while MAU growth decelerated from 33% in Q1 2025 to 14% in Q4 2025.

Management's 2026 guidance implies:

  • DAU growth of 20% (vs. 30% in 2025)
  • Revenue growth of 15-18% (vs. 39% in 2025)
  • Adjusted EBITDA margin of 25% (vs. 30% in 2025)

The market has extrapolated management's 2026 guidance as evidence of structural deceleration.

I think the market is missing a few factors.

First, 15-18% revenue growth on a $1b+ revenue base, combined with 25% EBITDA margins and 30%+ free cash flow margins, remains exceptional in the public markets. This context is needed.

Second, the slowdown is partially self-inflicted. Management is intentionally devoting more attention in 2026 to reinvesting in product and user experience after a period of aggressive revenue optimisation, taking a long-term view on the business.

Similar to Spotify (SPOT), Duolingo’s management constantly walks a fine line between balancing product investment and free user growth with revenue optimisation of paid subscribers. From 2022-2023, Spotify prioritised product investments and free user growth at the expense of subscriber revenue optimisation and the stock was severely punished. However, from 2024-2025, management shifted from this investment phase and began to better optimise near-term revenue and profitability (by raising subscription prices, layoffs, etc.), leading to EBIT margins reaching 15% in Q4 2025 (after being loss making for some periods during 2022-2023). Concurrent with the near-term boost in profitability, shares jumped over 10x from the 2022 lows to 2025.

I believe a similar pattern is unfolding here with Duolingo. Management admittedly over-optimised for short-term subscriber growth and revenue from 2024-2025, which came at the expense of free user growth (evidenced by MAU deceleration). In 2026, management is shifting their focus to product development and improving the free/lower-tier paid subscription offering, setting the foundations for strong MAU growth in 2027 and 2028. While this move weakens revenue growth and profitability in the short term, it is the right approach for long-term value creation.

Third, management’s guidance for 100m DAUs in 2028 implies a 24% CAGR from their latest MAU count of 53m. If we take their latest 2026 DAU forecast of 20%, this implies material acceleration in 2027 and 2028, supporting the thesis that this growth slowdown is a short-term blip.

Some readers might be considering whether management forecasts should be trusted. To me, this management team has a lot of credibility. From 2022-2025, management outperformed their annual revenue guidance by 3-10% and adjusted EBITDA guidance by 15-73%. In short, this is a management team that consistently underpromises and overdelivers.
